Synopsis: 
Winter 1982. The stay quiet American scientific expedition in the Antarctic is interrupted suddenly when a helicopter coming towards them with Norwegian flag desperately trying to chase a dog. However, the helicopter suffered an accident and and the only survivor is hurt killed after accidentally shot one of the twelve members of the American expedition. 

Given the ignorance of the facts surrounding the incident, the team receives at its base the dog as if it were one more, but they do not know is that under the external appearance of the dog is hiding an alien who had been buried in the snow hundreds thousands of years and which was located on the other Norwegian expedition. Soon, chaos will take over both the base and scientists: the alien can assume any form, including any of them, and thus impersonate any living thing without anyone noticing ... 

Production notes: 
- It is the second film version of the fantastic tale of John W. Campbell "The Thing from Another World", filmed in 1951 by Christian Nyby (version co-directed by Howard Hawks). 
- The video images to study the members of the American expedition, and which sees the Norwegian scientists measured the enormous artifact buried under the ice, are filmed by Nyby & Hawks in the 1951 version. 
- The ruins of the Norwegian camp visited by the protagonists are actually of the American camp in which the action takes place after the fire that takes place in the final scenes. 
- The cowboy hat worn by Kurt Russell in outdoor shots was a contribution from the actor himself, who decided to take a garment that will clearly distinguishable from the other actors and so the public knew who was the "star" at all times . 
- Its the time revolutionary special effects are the work of a young Rob Bottin, who was only 22 years was a pioneer in the use of animatronics. His work on the film was so intense it had to be replaced due to fatigue at some point by another name no less legendary in the field, Stan Winston. 
- The movie had the misfortune to coincide practically in his debut which for many was the highest grossing film in history, 'ET: The Extraterrestrial' by Steven Spielberg. All of a commercial failure and the public at the time, but over the years has been revalued to the point that today is considered a classic and not only one of the best films of John Carpenter, but throughout the 80s. 
- In the United States was released the same day that 'Blade Runner'.
